snippet: Many of the hospitals run by the armed forces are so small and the trickle of patients so thin that doctors and nurses say their ability to properly treat serious illnesses is compromised.
abstract: Many of nation's military hospitals are so small and have so few patients that doctors and nurses say it compromises their ability to properly diagnose and treat serious illnesses; hospitals run by armed forces are focus of evolving Pentagon plan to scale back system that cares for 1.35 million active-duty service members and their families (Series: Military Medicine).

byline.original: By SHARON LaFRANIERE and ANDREW W. LEHREN
byline.contributor: Sharon LaFraniere reported from Hinesville, and Andrew W. Lehren from New York. Kitty Bennett contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Many of the hospitals run by the armed forces are so small and the trickle of patients so thin that doctors and nurses say their ability to properly treat serious illnesses is compromised.

headline.main: Smaller Military Hospitals Said to Put Patients at Risk
headline.print_headline: Smaller Military Hospitals Said to Put Patients at Risk

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
